home.description: Discover the art of Goju Ryu Karate
home.heroTagline: The Hard and Soft Way of the Empty Hand
home.introText: Goju Ryu (剛柔流) is one of the main traditional Okinawan styles of karate, featuring a combination of hard and soft techniques. Developed by Chojun Miyagi in the early 20th century, this martial art emphasizes both strength and fluidity in movement.

theory.title: Theory
theory.description: Principles and knowledge of Goju Ryu
theory.terminologyDesc: Japanese terminology and vocabulary used in Goju Ryu
theory.historyDesc: The origins and evolution of Goju Ryu Karate
theory.philosophyDesc: Core principles and values of Goju Ryu
theory.kataDesc: Principles and theory behind traditional forms
theory.vitalPointsDesc: Study of pressure points and vulnerable areas

history.title: History
history.origins-desc: Goju-Ryu karate was developed in Okinawa, Japan in the early 20th century by Chojun Miyagi. The name 'Goju' comes from the 'hard-soft' principle of traditional Chinese martial arts and reflects the dual nature of the system: it combines hard striking techniques with softer, circular movements for both offense and defense.
history.development-desc: The growth and spread of Goju Ryu across the globe
history.lineage-desc: The key teachers and their contributions to the style

subsections.early-history-desc: The roots of Goju Ryu trace back to Chinese martial arts and their integration into Okinawan culture.
subsections.miyagi-era-desc: Chojun Miyagi's development and systematization of the Goju Ryu style in the 1920s and 1930s.
subsections.post-war-desc: The spread and evolution of Goju Ryu after World War II.
subsections.modern-era-desc: The contemporary development and global dissemination of Goju Ryu.

terminology.title: Karate Terminology
terminology.description: An overview of common Japanese terms used in Karate and Goju-Ryu.

tournament-terms-content.description: Terms commonly used in karate tournament settings.

general-terms-content.description: Commonly used Japanese terms in a martial arts context.

dojo.name: Dojo
dojo.english: Training hall, place of the way

sensei.name: Sensei
sensei.english: Teacher, instructor (one who has gone before)

numbers-content.description: Japanese numbering system used for counting in training.

equipment-weapons-content.description: Terms related to training equipment and traditional Okinawan weapons sometimes associated with Karate practice.

karate-goju-ryu-content.description: Fundamental terms specific to Karate and the Goju-Ryu style.

karate-do.name: Karate-Do
karate-do.english: The Way of the Empty Hand

karate-titles-content.description: Titles and ranks used in Karate.

phrases-etiquette-content.description: Common phrases and etiquette expressions used in the dojo.

arigato-gozaimasu.name: Arigato gozaimasu
arigato-gozaimasu.japanese: ありがとうございます

domo-arigato-gozaimashita.name: Domo arigato gozaimashita
domo-arigato-gozaimashita.japanese: どうもありがとうございました
domo-arigato-gozaimashita.english: Thank you very much (for what has been done)

shiko-dachi.name: Shiko Dachi
shiko-dachi.english: Square Stance / Horse Stance (feet at 45 degrees)

musubi-dachi.name: Musubi Dachi
musubi-dachi.english: Formal Attention Stance (heels together, feet out)

strikes-content.description: Basic striking techniques with hands and arms, other than punches (Uchi Waza).

vital-points-content.description: Terms for some vital points (Kyusho) targeted in Karate.

blocks-content.description: Common defensive techniques used to block or deflect attacks. Click "View" for a demonstration if available.
blocks-content.videoNotAvailableDescription: A video demonstration for this technique is not currently available.
blocks-content.videoLoadError: Could not load video for '{{file}}'. Please check that the file exists in public/video/blocks/.

age-uke.name: Age Uke
age-uke.details: Age Uke (Rising Block) is a fundamental upward blocking technique used to defend against attacks to the face or upper body. The forearm moves upwards to deflect the attack, while the other hand is withdrawn to the hip in preparation for a counter-attack.

gedan-barai.name: Gedan Barai
gedan-barai.details: Gedan Barai (Downward Sweep Block) is a sweeping downward block that defends against low attacks. The arm moves in a downward arc to deflect strikes aimed at the lower body, with the other arm retracting to the hip position.

soto-uke.name: Soto Uke
soto-uke.details: Soto Uke (Outside Block) is an outside-to-inside block used to deflect attacks coming from the outside. The forearm moves from outside to inside in a horizontal path to redirect the opponent's strike.

uchi-uke.name: Uchi Uke
uchi-uke.details: Uchi Uke (Inside Block) is an inside-to-outside block used to deflect attacks coming from the inside. The forearm moves from inside to outside in a horizontal path.

shuto-uke.name: Shuto Uke
shuto-uke.details: Shuto Uke (Knife Hand Block) is performed using the edge of the hand (shuto). It can be used to block attacks to the midsection or head, often with a circular motion.

empi-uke.name: Empi Uke
empi-uke.details: Empi Uke (Elbow Block) uses the elbow to block an incoming attack, often effective at close range and against strikes to the body.

kosa-uke.name: Kosa Uke
kosa-uke.details: Kosa Uke (Cross Block) involves crossing the wrists or forearms to create a barrier against an attack. It can be performed at various heights (jodan, chudan, gedan).

juji-uke.name: Juji Uke
juji-uke.details: Juji Uke (X-Block) uses the arms crossed in an 'X' shape to block an attack, typically a downward strike or kick. The hands can be open or closed.

haiwan-uke.name: Haiwan Uke
haiwan-uke.details: Haiwan Uke (Back Arm Block) uses the back of the forearm to block an incoming technique. It is often used to deflect strikes coming towards the side of the body or head.

osae-uke.name: Osae Uke
osae-uke.details: Osae Uke (Pressing Block) is a technique that presses down or pins an opponent's attack, often used to control an opponent's limb or create an opening.

terminology.noTermsAvailable: No terms available for this section.

practice.title: Practice
practice.bunkaiDesc: Application and analysis of kata techniques

study.title: Study Section
study.description: Interactive lessons and quizzes to enhance your knowledge
study.quizDesc: Test your knowledge on various topics.
study.noQuizzes: No quizzes available at the moment.
study.flashcardDesc: Review terms and concepts with flashcards.
study.noFlashcards: No flashcard sets available at the moment.

theory.title: Kata Theory
theory.description: Understanding the principles and practice of kata

sanchin.name: Sanchin
sanchin.description: The most fundamental kata in Goju Ryu, focusing on breathing, posture, and tension.
sanchin.history: Passed down from Kanryo Higaonna and further developed by Chojun Miyagi.
sanchin.culturalSignificance: Represents the essence of Goju Ryu and the connection of mind, body, and breath.

step1.title: Starting position and forward step
step1.description: Begin in natural stance facing forward

step3.title: Turn 180 degrees
step3.description: Perform three punches while maintaining proper breathing

step5.title: Maintain muscle tension
step5.description: Continue sequence with controlled movements and breathing

step6.title: Conclusion
step6.description: Maintain muscle tension throughout the entire form

gekisai-dai-ni.name: Gekisai Dai Ni
gekisai-dai-ni.description: The second of the Gekisai kata, building upon Gekisai Dai Ichi with more open-hand techniques.
gekisai-dai-ni.history: Developed by Chojun Miyagi, like Gekisai Dai Ichi, to make karate more accessible.
gekisai-dai-ni.culturalSignificance: Represents a progression in learning basic kata.

step1.title: Step 1: Placeholder Title
step1.description: Placeholder description for step 1 of Gekisai Dai Ni.

step2.title: Step 2: Placeholder Title
step2.description: Placeholder description for step 2 of Gekisai Dai Ni.

step3.title: Step 3: Placeholder Title
step3.description: Placeholder description for step 3 of Gekisai Dai Ni.

step4.title: Step 4: Placeholder Title
step4.description: Placeholder description for step 4 of Gekisai Dai Ni.

step5.title: Step 5: Placeholder Title
step5.description: Placeholder description for step 5 of Gekisai Dai Ni.

step6.title: Step 6: Placeholder Title
step6.description: Placeholder description for step 6 of Gekisai Dai Ni.

tensho.name: Tensho
tensho.description: A soft, circular kata embodying the 'Ju' (soft) aspects of Goju Ryu, complementary to Sanchin.
tensho.history: Developed by Chojun Miyagi as a counterpart to Sanchin.
tensho.culturalSignificance: Demonstrates the flowing and soft principles within Goju Ryu.

step1.title: Step 1: Placeholder Title
step1.description: Placeholder description for step 1 of Tensho.

step2.title: Step 2: Placeholder Title
step2.description: Placeholder description for step 2 of Tensho.

step3.title: Step 3: Placeholder Title
step3.description: Placeholder description for step 3 of Tensho.

step4.title: Step 4: Placeholder Title
step4.description: Placeholder description for step 4 of Tensho.

step5.title: Step 5: Placeholder Title
step5.description: Placeholder description for step 5 of Tensho.

shisochin.name: Shisochin
shisochin.description: A kata simulating attacks from four directions, emphasizing open-hand techniques.
shisochin.history: Derived from White Crane style, influenced by Kanryo Higaonna.
shisochin.culturalSignificance: Important for developing awareness and techniques against multiple opponents.

sanseru.name: Sanseru
sanseru.description: A dynamic kata attacking 36 vital points, combining hard and soft techniques.
sanseru.history: Likely from White Crane or Tiger style, passed down by Kanryo Higaonna.
sanseru.culturalSignificance: Symbolizes the complexity and effectiveness of Goju Ryu techniques.

saifa.name: Saifa
saifa.description: A kata focusing on close-quarters combat, with tearing and breaking techniques.
saifa.history: Originating from Chinese martial arts, introduced by Kanryo Higaonna.
saifa.culturalSignificance: Demonstrates practical application of Goju Ryu in self-defense.

seiyunchin.name: Seiyunchin
seiyunchin.description: A kata emphasizing low, stable stances and powerful pulling techniques, with no kicks.
seiyunchin.history: From Fujian, China, possibly Xingyi Quan or Monk Fist Boxing.
seiyunchin.culturalSignificance: Highlights the importance of unbalancing and control.

sepai.name: Sepai
sepai.description: A kata symbolizing the number 18, featuring circular movements and close-combat techniques.
sepai.history: Derived from White Crane style, passed down by Kanryo Higaonna.
sepai.culturalSignificance: Represents an advanced level of Goju Ryu, focusing on flow and grappling.

kururunfa.name: Kururunfa
kururunfa.meaning: Holding on Long and Striking Suddenly
kururunfa.description: A kata emphasizing the principle of 'holding and suddenly breaking,' with quick transitions.
kururunfa.history: From Fujian, China, specific style unknown.
kururunfa.culturalSignificance: Illustrates the use of deception and 'Muchimi' (sticky hands).

sesan.name: Sesan
sesan.description: One of the oldest Goju Ryu kata, featuring powerful, direct techniques and strong stances.
sesan.history: From Fujian, China, possibly Monk Fist Boxing or Lion's Fist.
sesan.culturalSignificance: Represents the ancient roots and power of Goju Ryu.

suparinpei.name: Suparinpei
suparinpei.description: The longest and most complex kata, encompassing the full spectrum of Goju Ryu techniques.
suparinpei.history: Derived from White Crane style, symbolizing the 108 earthly desires in Buddhism.
suparinpei.culturalSignificance: The culmination of Goju Ryu training, embodying hard and soft principles.

bunkai.title: Bunkai
bunkai.description: Application and analysis of kata techniques

gekisaiDaiIchi.title: Gekisai Dai Ichi Bunkai
gekisaiDaiIchi.description: Meaning 'Attack and Smash Number One', this kata was created by Chojun Miyagi in 1940. It was designed to be simpler than the traditional kata, making karate more accessible for young students and beginners. It introduces basic blocking, striking, and stance work.

bunkai1.name: Jodan Age Uke + Jodan Oi Zuki
bunkai1.footwork: Step back 45° into Heiko Sanchin Dachi + foot switch (in-out).
bunkai1.notes: Maintain Zanshin at all times. This applies to all bunkai!

bunkai2.name: Gedan Harai Uke
bunkai2.defense: Gedan Harai Uke (Low Sweeping Block - as strike and block simultaneously).
bunkai2.footwork: Step sideways outwards into Shiko Dachi (Square Stance).
bunkai2.notes: During hard contact training, do not attack the vital point [Hijitsume] but the forearm!

bunkai3.name: Chudan Yoko Uke + Mae Geri + Hiji Ate + Jodan Uraken Uchi
bunkai3.counterAttack: Gedan Mae Geri (Low Front Kick) + Chudan Hiji Ate (Mid-level Elbow Strike) + Jodan Uraken Uchi (High Back Fist Strike).
bunkai3.footwork: Sayu Tenshin (Side Evasion) + after Mae Geri, step forward into Zenkutsu Dachi (Forward Stance).
bunkai3.vitalPoints: E.g., [Kinteki] (Groin - Mae Geri) + [Ganka] (Solar Plexus) or [Suigetsu] (Solar Plexus - Hiji Ate) + [Jinchu] (Philtrum - Jodan Uraken Uchi).
bunkai3.notes: The low front kick is performed with the ball of the foot, front of the ankle, or shin, depending on distance. The attacker evades the Chudan Hiji Ate with a backward Suri Ashi (Sliding Foot).

bunkai4.name: Gedan Harai Uke + Chudan Gyaku Zuki
bunkai4.notes: Advanced students (from brown belt) should practice the block and counter-attack as one movement. The last two Bunkai Kumite should also be trained as a single unit by advanced students.

bunkai5.name: Ashi Barai + Yoko Shuto Uchi + Hikite + Fumikomi Geri
bunkai5.defense: Chudan Yoko Uke (Mid-level Side Block) + Tsukkami (Grasping).
bunkai5.counterAttack: Ashi Barai (Foot Sweep) + Yoko Shuto Uchi (Side Knife Hand Strike) + Fumikomi Geri (Stomping Kick).
bunkai5.vitalPoints: E.g., [Jinchu] (Philtrum) or Adam's apple [Nodo Botoku] (Yoko Shuto Uchi) + neck (Fumikomi Geri).
bunkai5.notes: After the Ashi Barai, quickly bring the foot back to prevent the opponent from attacking your leg. For the opponent's safety, the Yoko Shuto Uchi is not performed as a strike to a Kyusho, but more as a push, for example, on the chest and shoulder. The Fumikomi Geri can be performed with either leg, depending on how the opponent falls. However, in the Kata, it is the same leg used for the sweep. Advanced karateka can also make an irimi step and sweep the opponent from close range. In this advanced variation, the elbow is also clamped onto the chest.

bunkai6.name: Awase Zuki
bunkai6.defense: Nagashi Seiken Ura Uke (Flowing Fist Back Block - variant of Chudan Yoko Uke).
bunkai6.counterAttack: Awase Zuki (Combined Punch) + Awase Oshi (Combined Push).
bunkai6.footwork: Sayu Tenshin (Side Evasion) + step out into Zenkutsu Dachi (Forward Stance).
bunkai6.vitalPoints: E.g., [Ganka] (Solar Plexus - Gyaku Zuki) and [Inazuma] (Floating Ribs - Ura Zuki).
bunkai6.notes: The attack must be intercepted early. The Awase Zuki must first be powerfully focused before being continued as a push. To do this, you must first relax inwards and downwards and let the breath come in. The Awase Zuki is a smaller, closed-hand version of the Tora Guchi (Tiger Mouth).

gekisaiDaiNi.title: Gekisai Dai Ni Bunkai
gekisaiDaiNi.description: Meaning 'Attack and Smash Number Two', this kata is a continuation of Gekisai Dai Ichi, also created by Chojun Miyagi. It introduces slightly more advanced techniques and combinations, building on the foundation of the first Gekisai kata.

bunkai1.name: Hiki Uke
bunkai1.defense: Hiki Uke (Pulling Block) + switch grip with 'Sukui Uke' (Scooping Block).
bunkai1.footwork: Sayu Tenshin (Side Evasion) + forward Suri Ashi (Sliding Foot).
bunkai1.vitalPoints: E.g., Adam's apple [Nodo Botoke] and/or carotid artery [Matsukaze].
bunkai1.notes: When sliding in (Suri Ashi), hook the front foot around the attacker's front foot and apply a leg lock or place the front foot on the attacker's front foot. Clamp the attacking arm between your own upper arm and flank.

bunkai2.name: Nihon Hiki Uke
bunkai2.attack: Chudan Oi Zuki (Mid-level Lunge Punch) + Jodan Gyaku Zuki (High Reverse Punch).
bunkai2.footwork: Step back one foot or two Sayu Tenshin (Side Evasions).
bunkai2.notes: With the hand/arm of the second attack, you trap the other arm. Optionally, apply pressure with the big toe on the forefoot [Kori].

bunkai3.name: Tora Guchi
bunkai3.defense: Jodan Haishu Osae Uke (High Backhand Pressing Block).
bunkai3.counterAttack: Morote Tsukkami (Double Grasp) and Morote Oshi (Double Push).
bunkai3.footwork: Sayu Tenshin (Side Evasion) to Neko Ashi Dachi (Cat Stance), then step out. After the push, draw the back foot in.
bunkai3.vitalPoints: E.g., [Kinteki] (Groin) and carotid artery/Adam's apple ([Matsukaze]/[Nodo Botoke]).
bunkai3.notes: Intercept the attack early and execute with Muchimi (Sticky Hands).

saifa.title: Saifa Bunkai
saifa.description: Meaning 'To Smash and Tear', Saifa is one of the older classical kata passed down from Kanryo Higaonna. It emphasizes close-range fighting, with techniques for breaking balance, joint manipulation, and strikes to vital points. Its origins are believed to be from Southern Chinese martial arts.

bunkai1.name: Hazushi Waza + Otoshi Uke + Jodan Uraken Uchi
bunkai1.attack: 1. Kote Dori (Wrist Grab). 2. Chudan Gyaku Zuki (Mid-level Reverse Punch).
bunkai1.defense: 1. Hazushi Waza (Escape Technique). 2. Shotei Otoshi Uke (Palm Heel Dropping Block).
bunkai1.counterAttack: Jodan Uraken Uchi (High Back Fist Strike).
bunkai1.footwork: Step in 45° and turn into Heiko Dachi (Parallel Stance), then step in or back into Shiko Dachi (Square Stance).
bunkai1.notes: When stepping in, press the knuckles of the grabbed hand/arm against the opponent's forearm to weaken their grip (maintain pressure from the start). When escaping (Hazushi Waza), keep your arms close to your body. After the Otoshi Uke, grab the arm (do not grip immediately). The block can also be performed in Osae (Pressing) or Nagashi (Flowing) form.

bunkai2.name: Sukui Uke + Shotei Gedan Harai Uke + Hiza Ate + Mae Geri
bunkai2.attack: Chudan Oi Zuki (Mid-level Lunge Punch) + Mae Geri (Front Kick).
bunkai2.defense: Sukui Uke (Scooping Block) + Shotei Gedan Harai Uke (Palm Heel Low Sweeping Block).
bunkai2.counterAttack: Hiza Ate (Knee Strike) + Gedan Mae Geri (Low Front Kick).
bunkai2.footwork: From Heiko Dachi (Parallel Stance), step back with Suri Ashi (Sliding Foot) into Heiko Sanchin Dachi (Parallel Hourglass Stance).
bunkai2.vitalPoints: E.g., [Ein] (Groin - Hiza Geri) and [Kinteki] (Groin - Mae Geri).
bunkai2.notes: During the Sukui Uke, the other hand is used for protection. The attacker must immediately retract the Mae Geri. If the attacker, after retracting the Mae Geri, turns their torso sideways, perform the Mae Geri to the flank.

bunkai3.name: (Morote Hiki Uke +) Heiko Zuki
bunkai3.counterAttack: Morote Nukite Zuki (Double Spear Hand Thrust) + Morote Oshi (Double Push).
bunkai3.footwork: One foot back + forward Suri Ashi (Sliding Foot) or Ayumi Ashi (Stepping Foot) depending on distance. In case of a large, strong opponent: two Sayu Tenshin (Side Evasions).
bunkai3.vitalPoints: E.g., below the collarbone (Nukite) and [Ganka] (Solar Plexus - Oshi).
bunkai3.notes: The Morote Nukite Zuki and Morote Oshi are performed as much as possible in one movement.

bunkai4.name: (Morote) Gedan Furi Uchi
bunkai4.counterAttack: Morote Gedan Furi Uchi (Double Low Swinging Strike) + Kubi Nage (Neck Throw).
bunkai4.footwork: Kotai Ayumi Ashi (Alternating Stepping Foot), possibly turning away during the throw.
bunkai4.notes: Grab by the ears or by the jaw and hair.

bunkai5.name: Tettsui Uchi + TsukamiHiki + Ura Zuki + Jodan Gyaku 'Zuki'
bunkai5.defense: Gedan Uchi Nagashi Uke (Low Inside Flowing Block).
bunkai5.counterAttack: Tettsui Uchi (Hammer Fist Strike) + Tsukkamihiki (Grab and Pull) + Ura Zuki (Close Punch) + Jodan (Gyaku) Oshi (High (Reverse) Push).
bunkai5.footwork: Tai Sabaki (Body Evasion), then step out for the Ura Zuki and possibly step through for the push (Ayumi Ashi).
bunkai5.vitalPoints: E.g., fontanelle [Shomon] (Tettsui Uchi) + nose (Ura Zuki) + possibly Eye [Gansei] (Oshi).
bunkai5.notes: During the low block, keep the arm round and close to the body (do not 'scoop').

bunkai6.name: Haito Uchi
bunkai6.footwork: Sayu Tenshin (Side Evasion) to Neko Ashi Dachi (Cat Stance).
bunkai6.vitalPoints: E.g., Floating rib/kidneys [Ushiro Denko] or neck [Keichu].
bunkai6.notes: In the Kata, the Haito Uchi is a Chudan (Mid-level) technique.

bunkai7.name: Tora Guchi
bunkai7.defense: Jodan Haishu Osae Uke (High Backhand Pressing Block).
bunkai7.counterAttack: Morote Tsukkami (Double Grasp) and Morote Oshi (Double Push).
bunkai7.footwork: Sayu Tenshin (Side Evasion) to Neko Ashi Dachi (Cat Stance), then step out. After the push, draw the back foot in.
bunkai7.vitalPoints: E.g., [Kinteki] (Groin) and carotid artery/Adam's apple ([Matsukaze]/[Nodo Botoke]).
bunkai7.notes: Intercept the attack early and execute with Muchimi (Sticky Hands).

seiyunchin.title: Seiyunchin Bunkai
seiyunchin.description: Meaning 'To Control and Pull in Battle' or 'Marching Far Quietly', Seiyunchin is a powerful kata characterized by its strong, rooted stances and lack of kicks. It emphasizes close-range combat, grappling, and using the opponent's force against them. It is also derived from Chinese martial arts.

bunkai1.name: Morote Gedan Harai Uke
bunkai1.defense: Hazushi Waza (Escape Technique ~ 'Morote Gedan Harai Uke').
bunkai1.counterAttack: Hiza Geri (Knee Strike) or Mae Geri (Front Kick) (front or rear leg).
bunkai1.footwork: First one foot forward, then diagonally back to Shiko Dachi (Square Stance).
bunkai1.notes: It is important to first weaken the attacker's grip (double upward thrust). The meaning of dropping into Shiko Dachi is to learn to use your weight as power in escape techniques.

bunkai2.name: Sukui Uke + Hiki Uke + Hira Nukite Zuki
bunkai2.attack: Chudan Oi Zuki (Mid-level Lunge Punch) + Hikite (Pulling Hand).
bunkai2.counterAttack: Hira Nukite Zuki (Flat Spear Hand Thrust).
bunkai2.footwork: One foot back then step out into Shiko Dachi (Square Stance).
bunkai2.notes: With the Nukite Zuki, you first make contact, then apply power.

bunkai3.name: Hojo Oshi
bunkai3.attack: Chudan Oi Zuki Shotei (Mid-level Lunge Palm Heel Punch)
bunkai3.counterAttack: Chudan Nakadaka Ippon Ken Zuki (Mid-level Middle Finger Knuckle Punch) + Morote Shotei Hojo Oshi (Double Palm Heel Assisting Push)
bunkai3.footwork: Turn into Heiko Sanchin Dachi (Parallel Hourglass Stance) + Suri Ashi (Sliding Foot) forward during the push.
bunkai3.vitalPoints: E.g., [Danchu] (Chest Center - Chudan Nakadaka Ippon Ken Zuki).

bunkai4.name: Chudan Hiji Ate
bunkai4.footwork: One foot back, then forward with the other.

bunkai5.name: Hojo Uke + Gedan Harai Uke
bunkai5.defense: Sukui Uke (Scooping Block) + Shotei Gedan Harai Uke (Palm Heel Low Sweeping Block).
bunkai5.counterAttack: Hiza Ate (Knee Strike) + Gedan Mae Geri (Low Front Kick).
bunkai5.footwork: From Heiko Dachi (Parallel Stance), step back with Suri Ashi (Sliding Foot) into Heiko Sanchin Dachi (Parallel Hourglass Stance).
bunkai5.vitalPoints: E.g., [Ein] (Groin - Hiza Geri) and [Kinteki] (Groin - Mae Geri).
bunkai5.notes: During the Sukui Uke, the other hand is used for protection. The attacker must immediately retract the Mae Geri. If the attacker, after retracting the Mae Geri, turns their torso sideways, perform the Mae Geri to the flank.

bunkaiDetailPage.noBunkaiAvailable: No Bunkai available for this kata.
bunkaiDetailPage.videoDescription: Watch the bunkai demonstration video on YouTube.

bunkai.title: Bunkai Analysis
bunkai.introduction: Detailed analysis of the kata's applications.

shime.title: Shime (Test)
shime.introduction: Information about the Shime (test) of this kata.

notFound.title: Kata Not Found
notFound.message: The kata you are looking for does not exist in our database.

philosophy.title: Philosophy
philosophy.description: Core principles and values of Goju Ryu

kata.theory.title: Kata Theory
kata.theory.description: In-depth study of the principles and concepts behind Goju Ryu kata.
